instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND: What is PP2V5_NAND? PP2V5_NAND is a power rail that powers the NAND memory for the soldered on SSD of newer macbooks and must be present for the internal SSD to work. .

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) Stuck on 5V & DFU
threads.message:
Hi Guys. I have an A2142 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) board here for data recovery.
It's pulling 5V and auto detects in DFU mode.

The board was previously in at another shop, there was flux around the T2 Chip, <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> and PMIC.
I changed <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> - it appears prior shop attempted reflow on these components... not change or reball them. I am worried they damaged T2.

All <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> appear to measure good and sequence leading to 20V looks good.
I understand on this model that T2 chip required to get 20V.

Attempting "Revive" in Apple Configurator 2 returns error 4014.

I am looking into the possibility of swapping NAND to another board. Someone told me that could work for data recovery, looking for confirmation (Board <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)

Or in terms of repair on this board, if anyone has any advice on what else I can check.

TIA!!

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) Stuck on 5V & DFU
threads.message:
T2 doesn't require 20V input.
It should work before that; it decides to switch from 5V to 20V.
In fact, these boards can fully work with just 5V input.

Is very important the SSD to be in good working state, as T2 has its firmware partition there.
So check if all SSD voltages are there.

If someone else messed up with the board before, this may be hopeless project...

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) Stuck on 5V & DFU
threads.message:
I am missing SSD Voltages (<SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SDD0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SDD0</SIGNAL>)

I see in schematics that these lines are created by <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9500</CHIP>.

I have VIN on both these IC but noticed I am missing <SIGNAL>SSD0_VR_P2V5_EN</SIGNAL>. (Same goes for SSD1 / <CHIP>U9080</CHIP> & <CHIP>U9000</CHIP>)

I am wanting to learn more about how the SSD circuit works in these models and the power sequences - so that I can diagnose this issue.

Thanks so much for the help!

threads.title: MacBook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) Stuck on 5V & DFU
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground at all SSD power rails.
Power on sequence available for many boards, including T2 machines:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://logi.wiki/index.php/Main_Page#<SIGNAL>ALL_PAGES</SIGNAL>[/URL]
